description: Pre-written tech posts by Claude. Used for daily @FreeRiverHouse building in public.

posts.text: Building apps for kids is different. Every button needs to work on the first tap. Every error needs a friendly message. No second chances.
Our Unity test automation runs at 2 AM. I wake up to either green checkmarks or a to-do list. The machines never sleep.
VR development rule: if it makes you dizzy, it'll make your users sick. Testing on yourself is non-negotiable.
Writing code for children means writing code your future self can understand. Turns out that's just... good code.
The hardest part of game dev isn't the code. It's knowing when to stop adding features and ship something.
Automated tests caught a bug at 3 AM that would have taken me hours to find. The robots are earning their keep.
Meta Quest development: 80% waiting for builds, 15% fixing platform-specific bugs, 5% actual game code.
Every recipe in our cooking game was tested by actual kids. Their feedback: 'Make it more squishy.' Working on it.
Build once, test everywhere - except it's never 'once' and everywhere keeps adding new screen sizes.
The factory loop: build, test, fix, repeat. Let the machines do the boring parts while you sleep.
Shipping a kids' app means parental controls, COPPA compliance, and testing on devices with sticky screens. The glamorous life.
VR comfort settings are accessibility features. Motion sickness options aren't optional, they're mandatory.
Our PR agent posts automatically now. Sometimes automation is just teaching robots to do your job so you can do a better one.
Six apps in parallel, one developer. The secret? Shared architecture and a lot of copy-paste between projects.
Kids don't read tutorials. They tap everything. Design for chaos, build for curiosity.
Today's debugging session: 'why does this work in editor but crash on device?' Tomorrow's answer: threading.
Unity batch mode is beautiful. Headless builds, automated tests, no mouse required. The CLI always wins.
Building in public means sharing the ugly commits too. Not every day is a breakthrough.
A 4-year-old tested our app and found 3 bugs I missed. Hiring kids as QA: unethical but effective.
The best code review is a good night's sleep. Fresh eyes > tired debugging.
KidsChefStudio: 1035 lines of game code sat untouched for months. Today it finally runs. Sometimes you just need fresh eyes.
Fixed the XP system today. Cumulative thresholds, not incremental. Level 5 = 1000 XP total, not 1000 XP after level 4. Math matters.
BusinessIsBusiness: a VR office simulator where you manage virtual employees. Yes, it's as meta as it sounds.
Quest 3 passthrough makes office simulation weird. Your real desk, virtual coworkers. The future of remote work nobody asked for.
Set up a Telegram bot to post on X automatically. Now I'm teaching AI to do social media so I can do more coding.
The dashboard shows all our apps on a projector. Post-its with project status. Very startup, very 2015. Still works.
PizzaGelatoRush: a racing game with pizza delivery. Because Mario Kart + food delivery = obvious indie game pitch.
Unity 6 is fast. Like, noticeably fast. The editor doesn't freeze when I hit play anymore. Small wins.
Today I wrote more YAML than C#. CI/CD pipelines are the code nobody talks about at conferences.
Publishing a digital book is 10% writing, 90% figuring out why the PDF margins are wrong. Every. Single. Time.
Our cooking game has 8 chef levels. From Kitchen Helper to Master Chef. Gamification of Italian grandma's recipes.
Added a factory automation system. Code builds overnight, tests run, Telegram pings me if something breaks. Sleep-driven development.
The test framework wasn't installed. 23 tests, all failing because of one missing package. Unity dependency hell is real.
Music creation app for kids: drag and drop instruments, make beats. Teaching composition without sheet music.
Five different Unity projects, one shared codebase pattern. When you find something that works, copy it everywhere.
SwiftUI for the dashboard, Unity for the games, TypeScript for the bots. Modern indie dev is polyglot by necessity.
The PR agent now picks the most interesting commit of the day and tweets about it. Building in public, automated.
Onde: a digital publisher at the intersection of tech, spirituality, and art. Big words for a small operation with big dreams.
LaunchAgents on macOS: cron jobs but fancier. The factory runs at 2 AM, the PR posts at 9:30 PM. Robots on schedule.
Game dev for kids means every interaction needs sound feedback. Taps, swipes, success, failure. Audio is half the UX.
